title: Guns, Germs, and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies
Diamond places the development of human society in context, which is vital to understanding the development of medicine
Science Matters: Achieving Scientific Literacy
A clear and readable overview of scientific principles and how they apply in today’s world, including the world of medicine

container-title: Spangenburg, Ray, and Diane Kit Moser. The Birth of Science: Ancient Times to 1699
title: Internet History of Science Sourcebook. Available online
A rich resource of links related to every era of science history, broken down by disciplines, and exploring philosophical and ethical issues relevant to science and science history
The Beginnings of Western Science

A helpful explanation of the beginning of science and scientific thought. Though the emphasis is on science in general, there is a chapter on Greek and Roman medicine as well as medicine in medieval times
A Short History of the World
This helps place medical developments in context with world events
The Ascent of Science
A sweeping overview of the history of science from the Renaissance to the present
A highly readable book with key chapters on some of the most significant developments in medicine
A Short History of Medicine

While there have been many new discoveries since Ackerknecht last updated this book, his contributions are still important as they help the modern researcher better understand when certain discoveries were made and how viewpoints have changed over time
The Medieval Health Handbook
Originally published in Italy as Tacuinum sanitatis, this book describes medieval cures of the day
Source Book of Medical History
Clendening has collected excerpts from medical writings from as early as the time of the Egyptian Papyri, making this a very valuable reference work
Timetables of Medicine
An easy-to-assess chart/time line of medicine with overviews of each period and sidebars on key people and developments in medicine
The History of Medicine: Medicine in the Middle Ages

A heavily illustrated short book to introduce young people to what medicine was like during medieval times. Dawson is British so there is additional detail about the development of medicine in the British Isles
Dittrick Medical History Center at Case Western Reserve. Available online
This site provides helpful links to medical museum Web sites
History of Medicine
Though the book is written by only one author (a professor), each chapter focuses on the history of a single aspect of medicine, such as surgery or pharmacology. It is a helpful reference book
A Brief History of Disease, Science, and Medicine

Michael Kennedy was a vascular surgeon and now teaches first Further Resources 147 and second year medical students an introduction to clinical medicine course at the University of Southern California. The book started as a series of his lectures but he has woven the material together to offer a cohesive overview of medicine
Western Medicine: An Illustrated History
A variety of experts contribute chapters to this book that covers medicine from Hippocrates through the 20th century
A History of Medicine
An excellent overview of the world of medicine from paleopathology to microbiology
The Cambridge Illustrated History of Medicine

In essays written by experts in the field, this illustrated history traces the evolution of medicine from the contributions made by early Greek physicians through the Renaissance, Scientific Revolution, and 19th and 20th centuries up to current advances. Sidebars cover parallel social or political events and certain diseases
The Greatest Benefit to Mankind: A Medical History of Humanity
Over his lifetime, Porter wrote a great amount about the history of medicine, and this book is a valuable and readable detailed description of the history of medicine
A History of Public Health
While serious public health programs did not get underway until the 19th century, Rosen begins with some of the successes and failures of much earlier times
Doctors & Discoveries
This book focuses on the personalities behind the discoveries and adds a human dimension to the history of medicine
United States National Library, National Institutes of Health. Available online
A reliable resource for online information pertaining to the history of medicine
Available online
Information on medieval medicine with links to other medieval sites
Daily Life in the Middle Ages
This is a wonderfully thorough book about life in the middle ages, and it describes everything from what people ate to how they fought during medieval times
Migraine
A helpful book about understanding migraine headaches that happens to refer to Hildegard’s experiences
